content:
OK, I have no idea what happened, but I'll try to assist. The contact list is a file named abook.sqlite and the collected contact list is a file named history.sqlite. You could check in your profile folder to see if there is another profile that contains these files. that is, sometimes thunderbird makes a backup profile. You can check this by - clicking help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - click back one folder to the Profiles folder and then click to see if there is another profile. - if so, check for those files to see if they might have been recently used. if they look reasonable then exit thunderbird and copy and paste these files into your primary profile.

This may not work, but I am assuming that the file hasn't disappeared.
creator: davidsk

content:
Mi spiace ma come saprai Thunderbird è un software gratuito, non ci sono le risorse per offrire assistenza tecnica. Questo è solo un forum di utenti. Possiamo provare a darti una mano, ma il computer è nelle tue mani e senza la tua collaborazione non possiamo fare nulla.

Se non hai mai fatto un backup del profilo di Thunderbird, inizia a farne uno ora -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo potrebbe essere troppo tardi, ma comunque è meglio di niente.

Poi sta un po' a te decidere. Se i dati che devi recuperare sono veramente importati il mio suggerimento è di affidarti ad un tecnico della tua zona che possa operare direttamente sul computer.

Se invece vuoi proseguire qui posso indicarti come reperire le informazioni che ti ho chiesto sopra e come eventualmente tentare il recupero a partire dal backup.

content:
My regrets. I misunderstood. I was thinking of threading. You're using table view, I surmise. Try these steps:

FOR EXISTING FOLDERS These steps may help: To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: This must be done on an account by account basis.

  1. select table view - the icon just to right of 'quick filter' button above message list pane
  2. select a message folder and apply all desired attributes - View>sort by from menu bar (if not shown, click alt key)
  3. click the icon at right side of column display in message list pane
  4. select the entry near bottom 'Apply current view to...'
  5. highlight 'folder and children'
  6. move mouse left to see account name and move left again to display all account folders. Now CLICK. a small menu will appear to confirm setting all folders within that account.

I did a simple (okay, crude) video at https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4

The above apply to one account, so you would need to repeat for other accounts.
creator: davidsk

content:
Many thanks David, worked a treat

John

content:
Nella vecchia installazione di Thunderbird

  • Apri la rubrica
  • Click destro su una delle rubriche presenti -> Esporta
  • salva nel formato .csv
  • Ripeti se hai più di una rubrica

Nella nuova installazione di Thunderbird

  • Apri la rubrica
  • In basso a sinistra trovi il pulsante Importa
  • Nella procedura guidata scegli il file .csv
  • Ripeti se hai più file da importare
creator: @next

creator: kennethschmieder

content: If these are for the same email address, that explains what you are seeing. On the POP account, the messages reside on your PC. For the IMAP account, they live on the server with a copy on PC. Deleting from IMAP does not affect the POP account, because the message has already been downloaded to PC. You do not need both. If you want all messages accessible from PC or phone or other PCs, keep the IMAP account. The POP account could possibly have desired messages that have been downloaded from server. My recommendation is to go with the IMAP account for its flexibility. But, if you only use the PC as your primary repository for saved messages, then POP may be your choice.
creator: davidsk

content: Open Account Settings, Outgoing Server (SMTP), bottom of left pane. If the port is 587, the connection security is generally STARTTLS and the authentication method is 'normal password'. If the required security setting is 'none', the authentication should be 'password, transmitted insecurely'. Otherwise, contact your webhost for precise instructions.

content:
hal2010 said
It used to have a small color tab in the folder pane on the left hand side. Indicating that the folder was selected.

This ismall "color tab" is not the default to mark a selected folder in the folder pane. Maybe you used an add-on which is no longer compatible with actual Thunderbird versions. By default a selected folder in the folder pane is distinguished from other (non selected) folders by background color which depends on whether the selected folder is in focus or not. Exemple: in my picture th Sent folder is selected and not in focus
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thanks mapenzi that is interesting and useful. 'l'll have a look at my extensions. That coloured icon isn't very noticeable. It would be better to have a more eye catching indication.

content:
If it is an IMAP account R-click on the account name > Subscribe .... which opens the folder list. In the folder list check "Trash" (or "Trash") and click OK

If it is a POP account R-click on the account name and choose "New Folder". In the dialogue window type Trash as the folder name, verify that the new folder will be a subfolder of your account and click "Create Folder". A folder "Trash" with the typical icon of a trash bin should be created immediately as a folder in the POP account.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
my more button offers no such thing, so I don't know and can not get to what you do.

Right click on a parent folder (all folders have a parent, it may be "Local Folders" or an account name or another folder. Just the next item in the indents above your existing folders and select "new folder" or "New Sub folder" from the menu and fill in the name. Folders come under accounts, sub folders come under other folders. The menu offered changes you are offered one entry or the other, not both.
